newsitem.title: USA: Kellogg global volume up 2 percent in Q4.
newsitem.headline: Kellogg global volume up 2 percent in Q4.

text.p: Kellogg Co said Friday that its global volume grew two percent in the fourth quarter and rose by one percent for all of 1996.

"During the quarter, we achieved excellent growth in our convenience foods business and solid growth in our ready-to-eat cereal business outside the United States and the United Kingdom," Arnold Langbo, chairman, said in a statement. "While the U.S. and the U.K. remain challenging, we are encouraged by the contribution of new cereal products in both markets."
Langbo said Kellogg is "particularly pleased" with its new Kellogg's Honey Crunch Corn Flakes cereal, which was introduced in September 1996 in the United States.
He added the launch of more new cereal products in 1997 should add further strength to Kellogg's U.S. business.

"In 1996, our convenience foods volume grew at a double-digit rate for the second consecutive year," Langbo said. "We look forward to the continued growth of this business, both in the U.S., where we have recently acquired Lender's Bagels, and through expansion to new international markets."

Earlier, Kellogg reported fourth quarter operating earnings of $0.78 a share before charges, up from $0.77 a year ago, before charges. Net profit after charges was $0.42 a share in the quarter, compared with a year-ago loss of $0.33.
In the fourth quarter of 1996, charges included $75.7 million pretax for productivity and streamlining initiatives.
Kellogg said initiatives it took in 1995 and 1996 are expected to generate about $160 million in savings in 1997 and future years.
